column1: Sélestat (French: [selɛsta]; Alsatian: Schlettstàdt; German: Schlettstadt) is a commune in the north-east region of France. An administrative division (sous-préfecture) of the Bas-Rhin department
column2: the town lies on the Ill river
column3: 17 kilometres (11 mi) from the Rhine and the German border. Sélestat is located between the largest communes of Alsace
column4: Strasbourg and Mulhouse.

column2: Sélestat had a total population of 19
column4: which makes it the eighth most populous town in Alsace. During the Middle Ages and the Renaissance it was the third largest city in the region
column6: and it is ranked the third commune in Alsace for cultural heritage. Sélestat was founded in the 8th century as a port on the Ill and it experienced a long period of prosperity thanks to the trade in wine and a thriving religious and cultural life. It gradually declined after the Reformation and the French conquest in the 17th century. The town eventually experienced a new demographic growth in the second half of the 20th century when it became a small industrial and cultural centre.

column2: which includes the renowned Humanist Library and an imposing pair of medieval churches
column3: Sélestat is an important tourist destination in Alsace. It also benefits from its location on the Alsace wine road and its proximity to Haut-Kœnigsbourg castle. Aside from the medieval old town
column4: the commune of Sélestat encompasses a nature reserve including one of the largest riparian forests of France.

column1: The present name of the town is a Frenchification of the original Germanic name. It appeared soon after the French conquest in the 17th century. The town is called Schlettstàdt ([ˈʃlɛd̥ʃd̥ɐd̥]) in Alsatian and Schlettstadt  (German pronunciation: [ˈʃlet͡ʃtat]) in German.Sélestat was first mentioned in 727 as Sclastat. It was mentioned as Scalistati in 775
column3: as Sclezistat in 884 and as Slezestat in 1095. The current German name
column4: Schlettstadt
column6: although various spellings can be noticed on posterior documents
column8: Schletstat and Schlettstat. The French administration used various forms from the 17th to the 19th century
column11: Schelestadt). The town was officially known as Schlettstadt between 1871 and 1919
column12: when Alsace was part of the German Empire. Since 1920
column13: the town's French name is fixed as Sélestat.

column1: The origin of the name "Schlettstadt" is unclear. It probably derives from Germanic words slade or sclade meaning "marshes"
column2: and stat for "city". Sélestat would then be a "city in the marshes"
column3: a reference to its position in the Grand Ried
column4: a vast area subject to flooding that stretches over the centre of Alsace. Stat could also mean "area" rather than "city".A popular myth explains that the town takes its name from a dragon called Schletto that founded the settlement after opening up the nearby Lièpvre valley in the Vosges mountains.

column1: Sélestat was first mentioned in 727 AD but the town probably has an earlier Celtic or Roman origin. Archaeological findings provide evidence of human settlement during the Mesolithic
column2: the Neolithic and the Bronze Age. A large number of wood piles dating from the 1st and 2nd centuries AD were discovered around St. Quirin chapel
column3: suggesting a Roman settlement. At that time Sélestat might have already been a port on the river Ill.When Sélestat started to appear in written documents in the 8th century
column4: it may have been a market town or simply a village populated by fishermen and farmers. The area was part of the estate of Eberhard
column5: a member of the Alsatian ducal family
column6: who donated it to Murbach Abbey at the end of his life. In 775
column8: which indicates that the town must have had enough appropriate buildings and population to accommodate his court and troops.In the 1080s
column9: Sélestat was the property of Hildegard von Eguisheim
column12: the first member of the House of Hohenstaufen. Hildegard transformed the place into a religious centre when she founded St. Faith's Church
column13: which she gave to the Benedictines of Conques Abbey. Monks from Conques opened a priory next to the church in 1092. The House of Hohenstaufen quickly became the leading dynasty of the Holy Roman Empire
column14: which came to the imperial throne in 1152. Being under their protection
column15: the priory of Sélestat strongly influenced local life. Even though Sélestat constituted a distinct parish
column16: its priest had only limited power and the Benedictine prior was the true head of the municipality. At the end of the 12th century
column17: the Hohenstaufen dynasty gradually lost power and as a result the priory started to decline. The citizens used this opportunity to reduce the prior's dominance and secure the power of their parish. They started to build a new parish church in the 1220s. St. George's Church was designed in Gothic style and was significantly larger than St. Faith's Church
column18: another way to signify the end of Benedictine hegemony.

column2: ruler of the Holy Roman Empire in the 13th century
column3: realised that his dynasty was losing its power and granted freedoms to many cities in order to keep their allegiance. These cities became Free imperial cities and Sélestat became one of them in 1217. Under the new status Sélestat was able to build city walls and collect taxes on its own. Its serfs and settlers were freed. The German monarch Adolf of Nassau granted Sélestat a constitution in 1292. It was amended many times but it regulated local politics until 1789. Although the new status favoured trade and prosperity
column4: free cities in Alsace were afraid that they would not be defended by imperial forces if a conflict was to occur. So they decided to form an alliance called the Decapolis in 1354
column13: Sélestat and Mulhouse). The seat of the alliance was in Haguenau but its archives were kept in Sélestat. Because the town was the most centrally located
column14: it often hosted meetings of the association.The Benedictine priory was closed in 1424 after many years of decline. It had long lost its power to the local nobility that were gradually replaced by the bourgeoisie in the mid-14th century. Nevertheless
column15: Sélestat remained a religious centre even after the closing of the priory. Convents were established in the 13th century by Dominicans
column16: Knights Hospitaller and Franciscans. Several abbeys located outside of the town also had a residence in town. At the beginning of the 16th century
column17: Sélestat was a noted centre of Renaissance humanism thanks to its celebrated Latin school. Reformers Beatus Rhenanus and Martin Bucer were among the school's alumni. This school helped spread Protestant ideas among the population
column18: although the local authorities remained faithful to Rome. Erasmus of Rotterdam visited Sélestat four times between 1515 and 1522.Being a free city
column19: Sélestat attracted settlers from the region who sought protection
column20: freedom and a thriving economic environment. The first city wall
column23: and a third wall had to be erected in the 16th century as the city grew. At the end of the Middle Ages
column24: the population was estimated at between 5
column26: 000. It was then the fourth largest Alsatian town after Strasbourg (18
column29: 000 each). The local economy reached its zenith around 1500. It was centered on shipping and trade (mainly hay

column35: goods transited via the Ill river.

column1: The decline of the town started in the 1520s
column2: when the humanist school lost its former influence. The troubles surrounding the Protestant Reformation brought instability and unrest to the region. The town experienced the German Peasants' War in 1525 and its convents were sacked by a mob in 1534. During the same period Sélestat lost its pre-eminence in the Decapolis because the city of Mulhouse left the alliance in 1515 and was replaced by Landau in 1521
column3: moving the geographical centre of the alliance to the north.During the 17th century
column4: Alsace was one of the main battlefields of the Thirty Years War. Sélestat was seized by the Swedes in 1632 after a month-long siege. They surrendered the town to their French allies two years later. The local population long remained predominantly faithful to the House of Habsburg. The Peace of Westphalia (1648) formalised the annexation of the Decapolis by France. Sélestat was briefly occupied by the Germans during the Franco-Dutch War in 1674. The Treaties of Nijmegen (1679) that ended the war also abolished the Decapolis.At first
column5: Sélestat was a major strategic stronghold for the French. Located near the Rhine
column6: it controlled the access to the Vosges mountains and the rest of France. Vauban
column7: the foremost military architect at that time
column8: rebuilt the town walls between 1675 and 1691. However
column9: after the conquest of Strasbourg in 1681 Sélestat lost much of its strategic importance
column10: as Strasbourg was better located. But it remained a garrison town
column11: and the troops stationed there helped to improve the faltering local economy. Although Protestantism was not forbidden in Alsace
column12: French authorities largely encouraged Catholicism and opened three new convents in Sélestat. Jews were expelled from the town in 1642. During the French Revolution the population was extremely conservative and opposed to change. The new territorial organisation confirmed the decline of the town
column13: which did not become a prefecture and was not distinguished as a subprefecture until 1806
column14: when it replaced Barr in that capacity. Sélestat suffered from the Napoleonic wars as it was besieged and bombed by the Bavarians in 1814 and blockaded by a German coalition in 1815.

column1: Industry appeared very early in Sélestat. The town had already several factories at the beginning of the 19th century: a tilery
column3: 12 tanneries and 11 mills. Sélestat quickly became specialised in wire gauze making but it never became a large industrial centre
column4: remaining a small town with limited influence. The completion of the Strasbourg-Basel railway (1840)
column5: one of the first to be built in France
column6: did not lead to significant urban development. The town walls that still encircled the town were a significant factor in its economic and demographic stagnation. After the Franco-Prussian War of 1870
column7: Alsace and a part of Lorraine were annexed by the new German Empire. The German authorities demolished the city walls in 1874 and built new spacious neighbourhoods around the old town
column8: as they did in Strasbourg and Metz.Sélestat became French again after the First World War
column9: during which almost a thousand inhabitants died. It was part of the Third Reich during the Second World War. Its liberation took three months and ended in February 1945. The town is a recipient of the War Cross 1914–1918 and War Cross 1939–1945. Sélestat has experienced steady demographic and economic growth since 1945. Its population almost doubled between 1946 and 1999 and two industrial parks were built to accommodate new large factories. The service industry has enriched the town's economy since the 1970s with a large number of small businesses.South of the town
column11: a large broadcasting facility was used for transmitting on 1161 kHz and 1278 kHz in the medium-wave range. It was opened in 1948 and ceased to emit on 1 January 2016.

column1: Sélestat is one of the six subprefectures of the Bas-Rhin departement. As such it is at the head of the Sélestat-Erstein arrondissement. Sélestat is also the administrative centre of a canton including 28 other communes which primarily serve as a constituency for local elections. Sélestat is part of the 5th Bas-Rhin constituency for national elections. Since 2002
column2: the Member of the National Assembly for the constituency has been the Republican Antoine Herth.Sélestat is a member of a federation of communes with shared competencies: the Communauté de communes de Sélestat. Sélestat is its main town
column3: and it includes 11 neighbouring villages. It was created in 1995 to replace an older but similar structure founded in 1969. Sélestat is also the seat of the Central Alsace pays
column4: a structure aiming at developing the area.The town has had a council since 1292
column5: when it was granted a constitution under the Holy Roman Empire. The constitution shaped the local political system until the French Revolution of 1789. Since then
column6: the town has been administered as all the other communes of France. Its council currently comprises 33 councillors
column7: whose number is defined by law according to the size of the population. The town also has a mayor elected by the councillors.Alsace in general is a stronghold of the French right. The main French right-wing party
column9: currently holds a large majority in the council (26 councillors). Marcel Bauer
column11: is also a member of that party. Voters in Sélestat generally favour right-wing candidates at other elections as well
column12: although Sélestat was governed by the Socialist Party between 1989 and 2001.

column1: Sélestat is located at the very centre of Alsace
column2: near the limit separating the Bas-Rhin and Haut-Rhin departments
column3: which traditionally correspond to Lower and Upper Alsace
column4: respectively. The town is located between Strasbourg and Mulhouse
column5: the first being 42 kilometres (26 mi) north and the latter 57 kilometres (35 mi) south of the city. Sélestat is also located between Obernai (22 kilometres (14 mi)) and Colmar (21 kilometres (13 mi)). On the other side of the Rhine
column6: Freiburg im Breisgau is around 40 kilometres (25 mi) distant.Sélestat lies on the Alsace plains
column8: very fertile area that stretches between the Rhine and the Vosges mountains. The Ill flows parallel to the Rhine and crosses Sélestat. This river frequently branches and swells
column9: making the area very wet and subject to flooding. Sélestat is only 4 kilometres (2 mi) from the Vosges
column10: at the opening of one of the rare valleys crossing the mountain range and providing a connection to the rest of France. This valley corresponds to the course of the Giessen
column11: a 35 kilometres (22 mi) long tributary of the Ill. In contrast to the Ill
column12: which has a constant annual flow
column13: the Giessen is a mountain river subject to sudden increases in the water level
column14: especially during the spring thaw period. The Giessen passes north of the town and meets the Ill several kilometers to the east
column15: in Ebersmunster.The town itself is built on the Giessen alluvial fan so it is slightly higher than the rest of the Alsace plains. Much of its territory is however located on areas liable to flooding. Such areas are mostly located inside the Illwald natural reserve and comprise both forests and meadows. There the Ill forms more than 150 kilometres (93 mi) of waterways.

column12: Sélestat did not take advantage of industrialisation and rural exodus because its city wall and military function prevented urban growth. It reached its overpopulation threshold around 1830

column18: this rate progressively declined to match the national figure. Net migration figures remained slightly negative until 1990 because Sélestat and Central Alsace were on the margins of the metropolitan areas of Strasbourg and Colmar and lacked attractivity. Since 1990

column1: In terms of architecture the city is one of the richest and most varied among the smaller cities of Alsace. Although it is only the 8th most populous town in the region
column2: it has the third largest cultural heritage after Strasbourg and Colmar. Sélestat has 35 listed buildings and 119 additional sites that are indexed in the French list of cultural heritage monuments.

column1: The Humanist Library displays one of the oldest and most homogeneous collections of medieval manuscripts and Renaissance books in Europe. Its core is the still almost intact library of Beatus Rhenanus
column2: which was bequeathed to the city and has been maintained by it ever since. The institution also holds the books that belonged to the Latin school of Sélestat
column3: at which Rhenanus and many other reformers were educated around 1500. In 2011
column4: the library has been inscribed in the Unesco's Memory of the World Register.The library is open to both researchers and tourists
column5: with an exhibition displaying some of its most noteworthy items: an 8th-century lectionary
column6: the first books printed in Alsace

column8: and a 1521 document which contains the oldest record of a Christmas tree.Sélestat also has a museum dedicated to bread and baking and it is the seat of the FRAC d'Alsace

column1: Sélestat has two large and remarkable churches from the Middle Ages. St. Faith's Church is the oldest and a prime example of Romanesque architecture. Its design is related to similar buildings both in the Rhine region and in Lorraine. It was built during the second half of the 12th century to replace an earlier building. The church was renovated in the 19th century and a medieval death mask was found during this work. It is often attributed to Hildegard of Eguisheim
column3: and is now displayed in a crypt.St. George's Church has always served as the main parish church. It is often referred to as "the cathedral" because of its size
column4: but it has never been the seat of a diocese. Its construction started soon after 1200 and was completed at the beginning of the 15th century. Its design is pure Gothic
column5: save for a Romanesque side portal. The choir
column6: the last part to be completed
column7: is the most remarkable element. It is illuminated by 288 stained glass panels
column8: of which 55 date from the 15th century.Most of the convents of the town have disappeared; the Dominican convent is the only one to have retained much of its original appearance. It was built in the 13th century and still has its church and cloister. The Franciscan convent was completely destroyed
column9: apart from the choir of its church
column10: which now serves as a Protestant church. Sélestat also has an old granary that belonged to the Benedictine priory
column11: and a 16th-century commandery built by the Knights Hospitaller.The synagogue was built in 1890. Its architecture is typical of the region
column12: with a square shape and discreet neo-romanesque ornaments. Its cupola was destroyed in 1940 by the Nazis and never rebuilt. The Jewish cemetery
column14: was opened in 1622. It has several 18th century gravestones showing a Christian artistic influence.

column1: The old town comprises a large number of medieval and Renaissance buildings. The quai des Tanneurs ("tanners' quay") is one of the most picturesque streets in Alsace. A stream used to flow in the middle of the street until the beginning of the 20th century
column2: the relic of a former noxious-smelling trade
column3: since tanning required large amounts of flowing water for treating and washing animal skins. Most of the old tanner houses date back to the Middle Ages and have a tall attic to provide a ventilated space for drying leather. In the neighbouring streets
column4: rue des Oies ("geese street") and rue des Veaux ("calf street")
column5: many houses were covered with a coat of plaster in the 19th century in order to hide the timbering
column6: which was considered too rustic.Several hôtels particuliers (large townhouses) date from the Renaissance. Most of them have oriel windows that are characteristic of German Renaissance architecture. The grandest of these hôtels belonged to the Ebersmunster abbey and it has a large three-story granary. The Ziegler house has a beautiful oriel that shows the interest of the elite of that time in Antiquity. The oriel partly reflects Vitruvius's architectural legacy and displays the portraits of four key figures of Antiquity. Baroque architecture is visible on some later hôtels dating from the 17th and 18th century. French classical architecture and its main feature
column8: were largely employed in the 18th century. To reduce costs
column9: buildings were still built with timber framing
column10: but as this technique was considered too Germanic and rustic
column11: they were often covered with a rendering imitating stone.

They were in their turn destroyed in 1874. Only small portions survive: two bastions and the Porte de Strasbourg ("Strasbourg gate")

column1: The Illwald forest was designated a regional nature reserve in 2013. It covers 1
column3: 584 acres)
column4: almost half of the territory of Sélestat
column5: and is one of the largest riparian forests in France. It lies on the Ill
column6: which forms a complex hydrographic network there. The site is subject to flooding and it is characteristic of the Grand Ried
column7: a flat region located between the Ill and the Rhine that serves as a natural spillway for the two rivers.Common trees are oaks
column9: which tolerate wet soils. Because the phreatic table is very close to the surface
column10: soils hardly freeze in winter and drought rarely occurs in summer. The nature reserve also has meadows and reed beds. Common animals include a large variety of birds (storks
column13: amphibians and mammals (beavers). The reserve is home to the largest fallow deer population in France. This animal was introduced to the area in 1854.The Illwald contains three chapels that were originally pilgrimage destinations. The Schnellenbuhl chapel was built by Jesuits in 1683; Our Lady of the Oaks dates back to the 15th century but it was rebuilt after a fire in 1920; Our Lady of Peace was built in 1960
column14: and St. Anthony was founded in 1280 but rebuilt in 1930.

column11: Sélestat has organised a large flower procession through its old town. The "corso fleuri" is one of the biggest floral shows in eastern France. New floats are made each year around a theme and decorated with dahlias only. A carnaval procession is also held in March. It is the remnant of a very old tradition started by the town's butchers. Sélestat also has festivals dedicated to electronic music (Epidemic Experience)
